variant.question: The procedure for the pilot-in-command of an aircraft to be followed in case of intercepting a distress transmission is:

options.text: Record the position of the craft in distress if given, if possible take a bearing of the transmission, inform the appropriate RCC or ATS and, while awaiting instructions, proceed at your discretion towards the position given in the transmission
Hold at the position where the distress signal and/or message is received, co-ordinate the SAR operation by using the appropriate VHF and/or HF frequencies until released by a SAR unit.

Record the position of the craft in distress, take the bearing of transmission, inform the appropriate RCC or ATS using the appropriate VHF and/or HF frequencies, proceed on the most expeditious way towards the position given in transmission

Record the position of the transmission, proceed according to the flight plan, complete the SAR report form at the next airport, indicating where you can be reached in order to supply further information.

variant.question: You are flying over the NAT region when you intercept a distress call. You record the message, get a bearing on it from the ADF, and inform Shanwick control. The radio operator at Shanwick tells you to standby. What should you consider doing while awaiting instructions?

options.text: Proceed to the position given in the distress message.
Call your operator and advise him that you are now on SAR duty and will need to divert to nearest aerodrome at the end of your duty.
Descend to low level and carry out a surface search for ships.
Make a general call on 121.5 asking other airplanes to assist.

variant.question: What do you do, if feasible, after receiving a distress message from an aircraft near your position?

options.text: Acknowledge the transmission, and begin to search the aircraft in distress.
Hold at your current position and coordinate the SAR operation.
Enter a holding pattern and await instructions.
Record the bearing of the transmission, and continue on your way.

variant.question:
Three aircraft: (1), (2) and (3), arrive successively at ten minute intervals, overhead the scene of a recent aircraft accident.
(1) is unable to establish contact with the Search and Rescue Centre;(2) is able to contact the Search and Rescue Centre;(3) is a Search and Rescue helicopter.
The command of the situation is the responsibility of:

options.text: (1), then by mutual consent (2) and then (3).
(1) until the completion of operations.
(2), then by mutual consent (3) until the completion of operations.
(1), and then by mutual consent to (3).

variant.question: Whenever a distress transmission is intercepted by a pilot-in-command of an aircraft, the pilot shall, if feasible

options.text: acknowledge the distress transmission and record the position of the aircraft in distress if given.
hold at the position and coordinate the SAR operation.
enter into a holding pattern and wait for instructions.
record the position of the transmission and proceed according to the flight.

variant.question: If you are the first one who arrives at an area where an accident has happened, before search and rescue services arrive:

options.text: enter into a holding pattern and wait for an SAR aircraft to arrive.
if possible take a bearing on the transmission.
record the position of the craft in distress if given and if possible take a bearing on the transmission.
record the position of the craft in distress if given.

variant.question: If the first aircraft to reach the scene of an accident is not a search and rescue aircraft, what action must it take until the arrival of the first search and rescue aircraft?

options.text: Take charge of on-scene activities of all other arriving aircraft.
Overfly the wreckage every 10 minutes, searching for any surface-to-air visual signals.
Remain in the area, overflying the scene of the accident at a height of 1000 ft on a North-South heading.
Leave the area to avoid hampering subsequent search and rescue activities.

variant.question: Which of the following signals is a distress signal?

options.text: N
Y
V
X

variant.question: Whenever a distress signal and/or message or equivalent transmission is intercepted by the PIC of an aircraft, he shall:

options.text: record the position of the craft in distress if given and if possible take a bearing on the transmission.
enter into a holding pattern and wait for an SAR aircraft to arrive.
record the position of the craft in distress if given.
if possible take a bearing on the transmission.

variant.question:
When flying en-route you intercept an emergency transmission from an aircraft in distress
Your actions will include, where possible

options.text: Acknowledge the transmission, and begin to search the aircraft in distress.
Hold at your current position and coordinate the SAR operation.
Enter a holding pattern and await instructions.
Record the bearing of the transmission, and continue on your way.

variant.question: If you are the first one who arrives at an area where an accident has happened, before search and rescue services arrive

options.text: you are oblige to stay at the location of occurrence and take on charge the coordination.
you continue your flight because all aircraft have ELTs.
you descend in intervals of 10 minutes.
you descend to 1 000 ft and circle at the location of occurrence north to south.
